resources.string: Pinch to zoom, tap a friend
%s does not provide advice and information.
Calendar scheduling is only available on Android 4.0 and newer devices.
Good news: you can create a better, more supportive circle of friends for your self.\n\nSelect a step below to proceed.

Use this sliding scale to rate your experience of the activity you scheduled. Remember to rate what the activity was like WITH THAT PERSON.

By ""terrible"", we mean

• you didn't interact at all with the person, kind of like you were standing together in the same space but not talking

• the person you were with was rude

• doing the activity with this person lowered your mood

• you most likely will not interact with this person in this way again.

By "great", we mean

• your interaction with the person you were with was easy - you didnâ€™t even have to work at it

• the person you were with was easy to get along with

• doing this activity with this person really boosted your mood

• you will most likely do this again with this same person
What could you do this week?

The easiest way to meet people is to do something you like doing in the company of others.

Since the main focus is the activity you are doing, not just meeting others, there will be less pressure on you than in a setting where the whole purpose is to meet people. That sounds just plain stressful!

Even if you don't find anyone in particular that you enjoy, you will still have been doing something pleasant, something you like, and you won't feel like you wasted your time.
Join a club or Meetup group.\n\nThere are tons of groups in your area, doing a lot of the things to do!
Are you satisfied with your network?
Would you like to try again?
Would you like to do it again?
Social Force uses your contacts and communication logs to highlight your supporters.\n\nPlease restart the app once you\'ve added your contacts to your device.
Social Force uses your contacts to highlight supporters.\n\nPlease add contact records for people you\'ve called or texted.
Let\'s work together to BUILD and STRENGTHEN your supports!

If you're finding it hard to rate people, consider the following questions:

Do I walk away from time with this person feeling happy? Understood? Valued?

Do I walk away from time with this person feeling spent? Used? Unsatisfied?

How does interacting with this person change my mood - up or down?

How does interacting with this person change how I feel about myself?

Practical Support: Who will drive you to the hospital? Lend you money?

Advice: Who do you go to for help when you don't know how to do something? When you don't feel well? When you need help navigating a tricky situation?

Companionship: Who do you walk around a park with? Who would spend a quiet afternoon with you? Who shares your tears and your joys?

Emotional Support: Who do you go to for encouragement? understanding? to share your feelings? to help lift your mood?
Join a Club or Meetup Group
There are tons of groups in your area, doing a lot of the things you like to do! If meetup.com isn\'t right for you, there are other networks out there - find them and look for what interests you.
Volunteering is a great way to do something you think is worthwhile, while giving you a chance to meet people with similar interests and hearts.

Even if you\'re feeling down, depressed, or uncomfortable, putting a smile on your face biologically signals to others that you are open. Friendliness attracts friends! Smiles can open you up to having something to smile about!

Pick a day, a week, or any time period and vow to say "yes"" to every invitation, opportunity, and date. If no invitations come along, pick another date! Give yourself plenty of chances to interact with new people.

Go back through your contacts - are there people in the "neutral" or ""don\'t know" category that you want to know better? Is there anyone missing or anyone you just met that might make a potential friend?
